During that stay, a majorly scary bout of severe weather pounded a large area of the upper midwest, including the Pittsburgh area - with unprecedented thunderstorm activity, flooding, and Tornadoes. Many of the hotel guests gathered in the Bar to drink and watch the Weather Channel and local weather station reports coming in - there were myriad Tornado watches and warnings - some not very far from Pittsburgh.

I pounded a few beers and single malt scotches during that scary period, and ate in the bar every night.

This last stay this past week - we came in to order food - and were informed that since it was after 10:00 pm - no food was available. I'll say it again - LAME! EPIC FAIL!

I like this little bar - but it's hard for me to give it more than 3 stars due to the food hours...

Only eat at Braddock's if you aren't hungry and don't like too much to drink. Service couldn't be slower. Sat for a half hour until they finally took our order. Food arrived a half hour or so later - we had been there over an hour. No offers for refills, so you'll be fine to drive home. Maybe they don't like selling their booze....but if you're looking for food and drink, find another spot.

First of all, the atmosphere of the Renaissance itself is fantastic. I came here on the Cultural District's Winter Gallery Crawl last night for appetizers. Our waitress was cheerful and our drinks were never empty (I down water like a fish, so finding waitstaff that can keep up is impressive). 

I ordered the cheese board and my boyfriend ordered the "Strip District" mussels and frites. The mixed berry compote served with the board was phenomenal when paired with one of the spicy cheeses. Apples, crostinis, and roasted nuts added great texture and the cheeses themselves were yummy. The mussels were served with kielbasa to achieve the "Strip District"-esque theme. I can't decide what was better: the frites or just the aoli that they were served with.

Braddock's is a small bar inside of the Renaissance hotel.  We were in town for only one night, to go to the Pirates game, and we were staying at the hotel.  After the game, we were pretty tired but up for a drink.

We headed here immediately after the game, and the bar wasn't too crowded.  Right around the time we finished our drinks, there was hardly any standing room left!

I was happy with my $6 gin & tonic, but there wasn't much about the bar keeping me tuned in and interested in staying for another drink.

During Happy Hour, all well drinks are only $4.  There's also a small food menu.

Worth a visit if you're staying in the hotel or passing by and craving a cocktail.  Braddock's isn't really a place to party or consider a destination.

Back in Pittsburgh. I arrived at the hotel late after working. I grabbed a table in Braddock's for a late meal and to watch Monday Night Football.

I had mussels & frites with a Braddock's smash cocktail. The food and drink were excellent. Braddock's has a great menu.

My mom was in town for a conference, and I thought it was the perfect opportunity to use my Groupon to Braddock's.  A short walk from her hotel on a beautiful day, we strolled in to the lobby of the Renaissance hotel to find the restaurant.  What a GORGEOUS hotel!  It makes me want to wear a long red dress and walk slowly down a staircase to greet a crowd of admirers.  Classy place.

The restaurant has a classy vibe too - leather booths, white tablecloths, and dim lights.  We started with cocktails - alas, the cocktail menu is not on the website (or I'm dumb and can't find it) - but whatever we had, it was delicious.  I believe it was marked as the house specialty cocktail.  I wasn't sure I'd like it because sometimes I'm a little iffy on whiskey, but it was actually fruity and delicious.  We both loved it.

Next, we split the goat cheese and beet salad (which they put on separate plates for us), and it was great.  Sweet beets, amazing fried goat cheese, tasty vinaigrette.  Oh - and we also got a soft, warm baguette wrapped in paper, with a plate of sweet butter.

For my entree, I had mussels and frites "Billi-bi" style, which means in a saffron-cream broth.  The frites were served with an aioli.  I also had a side of garlic spinach.  The entree didn't bowl me over - mussels were well prepared and the broth was tasty, but it wasn't long before it seemed too rich for me, and became a little hard to eat.  There was just so much broth and it was so creamy!  The spinach did a nice job of cutting through the heavy meal, but the overall effect was still a bit much. 

Way too full for dessert!  I think our meal came to about $90 (Mom got the daily special, a fish dish) - so that's $90 for two drinks, one salad, a side dish, and two entrees.  It's pricey.  The Groupon helped. I think I would return though, it made a good impression.  Our server felt a bit rushed - she didn't really connect with us and always seemed to be moving quickly, but that's okay.  There weren't many people in the restaurant at all, which was kind of sad on a Friday.  More people should give this place a shot!

I didn't eat here. We came to have some whiskey and were not disappointed in the slightest. Huge selection of bourbon with a good amount of rye and scotch as well. The Braddock Smash is a fantastic cocktail. The lobby/lounge area that is shared with the hotel is really epic. Definitely one of the best spots in the city in terms of outrageous use of marble to tip folks off to the amount of wealth that used to be concentrated in the area. I'll definitely be back for a drink and hopefully dinner next time.

This place was hopping and we enjoyed grabbing a drink and appetizer.  There is a street-view bar, the lobby of the hotel and then the restaurant in the back.  We actually ordered at the bar and went and sat at the long table near the video fish tank to people watch and chat.  The server was Nicole and she was very nice and didn't mind serving us across the lobby.    We had been walking around the cultural district and just stopping in and soaking up the atmosphere of beautiful Pittsburgh.

I recently went there for the first time. I was impressed with the dÃ©cor but also immediately put off my the service. I went for brunch on a Sunday, when I walked in there was not a host or server around to seat our party. Someone from the kitchen staff that was at the omelette station told us to just seat ourselves, so we did. 
It was not busy at all, there was only one other table there. We waited 10min before even being greeted by a server.

I went with the intentions of having breakfast which changed quickly after looking at the brunch buffet. The food had been sitting for a long time and you could tell (it looked very dried out). I still decided to get breakfast since there was an omelette station and Belgium waffle station that were both freshly made. 2 others in our party ordered the crab cake and steamed mussels and we're please with both.

I personally would not go back here for brunch or suggest the place to anyone else.

We had breakfast here during our last stay at the hotel.  The food was incredible and that's a term I use sparingly.  I would give it 5 stars but I don't believe one breakfast is enough evidence to warrant giving it my highest rating.  Completely recommend it as the best breakfast in the Cultural district.

We had a bad experience once at Braddocks and the response to our complaint was amazing. We are now frequent customers for a pre or post theater dinner and drink. 
A solid menu, not the most interesting but always good. 

I love that they will serve both menus in the restaurant or Streetside. I prefer Streetside just because I like the ambiance of a bar setting, but both are nice. 
Also, the sound level is great. They don't blast music and the acoustics allow you to hear the people you're dining with. 

My only complaint is that they over-cook their burgers, but that is more than compensated by the fact that their other food options are quite good. I highly recommend the short rib pierogies.

I have had three meals in the pub which shares the menu with the full service restaurant and I have been really really happy each time. What did I have? Why mussels in white wine of course w/ frites! Excellent. As a former resident of the Pacific Northwest I know a little something about shellfish. The mussels at Braddock's are by far the best I have had in Pittsburgh. Each time I ordered them a large steaming bowl was brought to the table. Each time every single mussel was delicious, plump and perfectly prepared. Not a single bad mussel...not one! The frites are crisp as one would expect with a Belgian preparation. They come with a garlic mayo dip. My friend had a Reuben made with portabello mushrooms rather than meat and it was excellent (I tried some:) My daughter had mac and cheese that was not your boxed version. The beer list is excellent with a great representation of local beers, nationals and import. I have yet to see the wine list, but expect that it has nice offerings. This has become my go to place when downtown for a chill beer and excellent shellfish.

The food was decent, but overpriced.  Although the restaurant was mostly empty, it took some time for us to be seated. The service was friendly and responsive.  There was nothing at all wrong with our experience, there are simply better alternatives available.

Not recommended.

I tried Braddock's tonight because of the Groupon. As others mentioned, the hotel is gorgeous and the restaurant has a really nice feel or ambiance.

They brought me complementary fresh baked bread with some unsalted butter with some sea salt on top. Very nice! Had the half portion of mussels as an appetizer which was well done except only a little broth at the bottom making it hard to dip. The broth was awesome for bread sopping.

I would award another star except my main dish of Lobster Cassoulet had overcooked lobster. Basically all claw meat which was chewy.

Service is good, and I think things are actually fairly priced (website menu is accurate). Parking was a little tricky, I ended up at the garage across the street.

The four stars are for service and drinks, as I've only eaten a couple of apps here and haven't been particularly wowed by them.  But Street Side is primarily a bar, and that it does very well.  They have what's probably the best whisk(e)y menu in Pittsburgh, with tasting flights available by style, label, and country, and they also serve our local Wigle.  The bartenders are incredibly friendly and prompt with service despite the length of the bar.  There's a nice lounge on the ground floor of the hotel where you can wait for a seat at the bar, and they serve drinks in there as well.  Much more casual than the Brasserie; you can get away with jeans here.

If you like whiskey, check out Street Side.  If you're looking for food, stick with the Brasserie or another restaurant in the area.  Discount certs are available on Restaurant.com if you're feeling cheap, and they ARE good on alcohol.

Braddock's is a nice downtown venue that serves very good food - I would certainly recommend it as an excellent pre-theater dining option.

I selected Braddock's because of its location - Heinz Hall is on the next block.  The restaurant is also near the Byham Theater and the Benedum Center.  There is a convenient city parking garage directly across 6th Street, where event parking was a very reasonable $7.  The restaurant itself is directly inside the very pleasant Renaissance Pittsburgh, complete with an old-fashioned lobby.

While the restaurant uses the term "Brasserie," there didn't seem to be all that much French or Belgian about the establishment.  Most dishes are generally very good American-style options, mostly on the order of a steakhouse.  They did offer a french onion soup and bouillabaisse, as well as steak frites.  The steak options were cooked well and the filet mignon was very tender.  They did use a fair amount of bearnaise sauce, however, which made the dish feel a little heavy and somewhat dated.  The mashed potatoes were good, although not particularly inspired, while the asparagus was maybe a little limp.   The portions here are very generous here.  I ordered a caesar salad as a starter, and there as no way to finish the massive plates of green.  The dressing was excellent, however, and clearly made in house, with fresh notes of lemon.  There was certainly no possibility of dessert.  

The cocktails were very good, maybe the highlight. I had a well-made Martinez, while my table-mates enjoyed the whiskey smash.  The service was very, very good.  The server was friendly and responsive, and the food arrived quickly.  The manager even stopped by to ask whether we enjoyed our meal.  Before the salads and appetizers, the server came by with complimentary bread and butter.  The bread was a very good, if not superlative, baguette and the butter was served perfectly - at room temperature and generously salted.

Since this restaurant is in the lobby of the Renaissance, you should know that the bathrooms are on the second story.  There is an elevator in the lobby (as well as a lovely staircase) to provide access, but if you have limited mobility, you should note that the bathrooms are a bit far away from the dining area.  The bathrooms themselves were spacious and very clean - I suspect they are also used for function rooms on the second floor.

If you are downtown and near the theaters for dinner, Braddock's is a great option.  You will enjoy an excellent drink, good (if not all that adventurous) food, and a very nice, unpretentious atmosphere.  Enjoy!

We had a pleasant time atmosphere was nice and the server was very attentive. Wasnt overly impressed with the food, but did enjoy the beet goat cheese salad and the French onion soup however. All and all I would go back but probably  just for apps.
Terrible awful worst in a long time . Drink more wine because you are going to need it
My husband & I enjoyed an anniversary date here.  Service & atmosphere was great!  I recommend trying this establishment. I had the steak frites and my husband enjoyed the seafood pasta!  Go & enjoy!

Good food. Good service. We had two appetizers. The brucetta was good. I really liked the goat cheese on it. And we had the crab cake. It was not fried, which was great because you could actually taste the crab meat.

 I had the risotto. It was a little heavy on the pepper in my opinion, but I'm not really big on pepper. 

My dad had the salmon. I had a bite and the whiskey glaze was very good. 

For dessert, we had the very cobbler. Sweet with a nice berry taste. Not very much crumble topping. 

Overall, it was a good meal. Worth a try if you're downtown looking for a nice place to eat.

My quest for super-delicious mussels in Pittsburgh led me to Braddock. There are 4 different sauces to choose from. They were really good....  but not 5 star.  I am still looking.  I have been to Point Breugge and Dish as well (specifically for mussels ), and I think Dish is in the lead so far.

Love this place. Been four times,  and wish i could go back more often. The French dip is to die for. The fries oh my, v good! Mixed salad was tangy and freshly prepared. Both the bar and restaurant are fab for a date.

This is a nice restaurant, classic looking.  High back seating and few tables spread throughout.  My son had the Pgh Big Ugly reuben and it was a bit much.  It was sloppy and difficult to bit.  It was an ok take on a great sandwich.  I hate to say Braddock's ruined it but they really went overboard with all the "add-ins" on this standard sandwich.  The salmon, well, it was salmon...take notes from Georgetowne Inn's chef because they have mastered this dish.  Braddock's is convenient if you do not want to try to endure Pgh's wintery weather and you are staying at the Renaissance.

I am rounding down from 3.5 here. This place is somewhat overrated--maybe a place to impress a date or perhaps an expense account dinner. But while I would eat here again, I would not choose to eat here again.

First, Braddock's is a bit pricey and some of the appetizer portions are much smaller than you would expect for the price. Second, there is a large selection of entrees and as a restaurant in a higher-end hotel there is the requisite elegance. Third, the salads and bread are great and they are food allergy friendly. Finally, the entrees are ok at best. Some of the dishes try too hard and are overly complicated which is not always a good thing.

Overall, however, I prefer Alihan's across the street for what I think is consistently better food at a much lower price (which also includes a free glass of wine).

I stayed in the hotel and had both breakfast and lunch there on a Saturday.
Breakfast:  I had the french toast and it was unremarkable.  Two slices of battered bread.  Definitely a bonus point for having real maple syrup.  My partner had the egg white omelet.  It came with everything - toast, potatoes.  All very good.  I was hungry after the small french toast portion.
Lunch:  Mostly inedible.  The french onion soup was so salty it was bitter.  The caesar with a chick breast tasted mostly of artificial lemon with a dried out tasteless breast.  The hot bread and fresh butter was great. 
In both meals the atmosphere and the service were very nice.  The meals should be skipped.

Truthfully, we ate at this place because we stayed at the hotel and had a restaurant.com coupon.  We paid $4 for the $20 coupon - had to use it. 

This restaurant serves mediocre food at a high price.  Again, the coupon made us do it to ourselves.   Would not eat here if we were paying the full tab.   There are so many better options in the city.  Do yourself a favor...keep scrolling.

This place is hit or miss.  I have stayed at the Renaissance twice a week for the past 12 weeks and have consistently eaten here for breakfast.  Some days, I've had mold in my fruit, other days, my eggs have been runny and cold.  From burnt toast to cold coffee, there is always something wrong with my meal.  You are probably wondering why I've not switched to a different place.  Mostly because there are no other options.  I'm going to McDonald's tomorrow.

This is my boyfriend and mine's favorite place to go to when we want to treat ourselves nice.   Everything about the place is classy in my opinion.  The servers and waiters are very professional.  With that said, they have top notch gnocchi which I often times get cravings for.  I haven't had a single meal there I didn't like.  I like that they buy local, and their specials usually reflect that.  Their portions are huuuge, and the price is reasonable for the quality and amount of food you get.  Their desserts are also spectacular, but I must say I am disappointed they changed their apple tart (The first time we got it, it came with ice cream and baked basil on top - yum yum yum).  I would definitely and have recommended this restaurant to friends and family.

We took my mom here for her birthday and we loved it!  The service was great.  We ordered the bruschetta for our appetizer and it was perfect, and the seared scallops that I ordered for my main dish were just the right portion and were delicious!  I'm only sad that they stopped accepting restaurants.com gift cards.

My fiance and I are staying at the Renaissance.  We stopped at Braddock's the hotel bar. We cannot say enough good things about Michael. He was awesome! We were having a pretty bad night and he turned it around. He was just what we needed. Super friendly and hospitable.  I highly suggest dropping in for a drink or dessert. Both were superb!

Went to lunch with my meet up group to celebrate St. Patrick's day parade here. The restaurant is located inside the grand Pittsburgh Renaissance hotel.

We started out with lamb shepherd's pie and bruschetta on crackers for appetizers. They both were so good that I really had to restrain myself from eating more since i wanted to save room for lunch.

They serve regular beverages in mason jars along with traditional drinks and wine. They offer a lunch pairing of either soup and salad or soup and sandwich for $12.00.
Our waitress was very friendly and attentive to our needs I opted for their French onion soup and spinach salad. She explained that my soup selection would be $1.50 up charge before I placed my order. She also explained these items would be half portions.

She also suggested I add one of the additional toppings. In my case I choose shrimp.The lady sitting next to me ordered a corned beef sandwich which the call "the big ugly" which comes with a side of fries.

When my meal arrived I was glad I ordered the combo. Their servings are huge!!! The French onion soup was to die for and the shrimp on my salad were full size and cooked just right.

The lady who ordered "the big ugly" got a portion so huge that you would need at least 2 or even 3 people to finish it. She absolutely loved it and as expected ended up taking most of it home.

The staff made sure our beverages were always full and cleared used plates upon asking first. For an elegant restaurant I was glad we were able to dress casual here.

They do offer Wi-Fi but for some reason if you wish to utilize it then you must give them your e-mail address. Restrooms are located on the 2nd floor where you can either use and elevator or walk their grand staircase which gives you a beautiful atrium view of the lobby area and entrance to the restaurant.

In the front entrance there is a bar called Braddock's Streetside. We didn't go there since we had so much to eat and drink here. I'm especially grateful when I am told upfront what my charges are as well as great food and professional service.

Located next to the Byhum Theater this restaurant makes a great place for either pre or after theater dining as well. Hats off for a wonderful luncheon!!!
Service was great and very attentive. My wife got the Asian salad and I got the Pittsburgher sandwich...both delicious. Very upscale downtown restaurant

My below-average rating is due to my most recent visit. I've been here a handful of times as the location is quite convenient to the theatre venues in town. Food is decent, but good food isn't hard to come by so it's really the service that makes the experience in my opinion. Our party of 7 has a reservation at noon before a 2p show last week. We were all on time and seated promptly and there were NOT many people there until probably 15-30 min after our arrival. Our waiter Gabe was never overly friendly and our drinks were empty (both waters and paid beverages) more than full. Many of us had to ask for refills. I ordered a burger done medium and when it was brought out, it was burned. Not well done -burned.  When I told the waiter, he looked at me disgusted and *literally* didn't say a word, just walked away with my plate. Who I assume was the manager came over probably 10 min later and gave a half apology, blamed being busy and having a new chef. She did comp my wine but I never expected that. Lunch took so long that we walked into our show at the Byham (...next door) just 10 min before the show started. Very underwhelmed at this point and uncertain on returning. I am however attaching a picture of my scallops from a previous dinner there that were delicious.

The skinny: great food, booze and service. 

I've stayed at the Renaissance twice in the last year and eaten at Braddock's twice. Both times, I was impressed. The first time was my pre-Yelp days, but I actually took a pic of the sandwich, because it was such a yummy monstrosity. It might have been a monte Cristo? 

This time, we ordered the pork belly and Mac n cini. Both were fantastic. The pork belly came with grits and chicharrones. The whole dish just worked well together. The other dish was essentially deep fried risotto balls (with just a hint of spice). Also excellent. I got the double chocolate mousse to go, and I was very happy in our hotel room when I dove into it about an hour later. 

A few other comments. Matt was our bartender/waiter. Very big props to Matt. I'm always a fan of people who are personable and knowledgeable. Matt is. I also like the newspaper style menu. Lastly, if you like bourbon or whiskey in general, they have a great selection.
Solid 5/7...only problem is if you're a full blown alcoholic it takes about 45 Minutes to get a drink ...other than that not a bad experience

Went here for date night with my fiance. 

What we sampled: 
Braddock Smash (I had this and thought that it was well made and tasty)
Moscow Mule (My fiance was not impressed that it was not in a copper mug and was definitely not as good as the one you can get at Alchemy N Ale)
1/2 Charcuterie Board (meh.  It was pretty disappointing selection wise and overall was too cold and boring)
Cowboy Steak (Perfectly cooked and delicious the mashed potatoes were just ok but the asparagus were great.  When I tried to reheat this I found out that the demi glace was thickened with corn starch because everything started getting thick in the pan when heating up (did not work at all)). 
Croissant Bread Pudding (It was ok, but was definitely better when we asked for more creme anglaise and caramel sauce)

Overall it was a decent meal, but I don't think that I would return.

Braddock's should be admired for it's dedication to buying local.  Everything is described to you by friendly servers with where things come from.  Very impressive.  Especially for a hotel restaurant!  I think a lot of people have a common misconception that all hotel restaurants must be a chain of some sort.  It's nice that the Renaissance welcomes them in. 

The outer part of Braddock's is just a bar area or "Braddock's Streetside."  The back part of Braddock's is a fancy dining room.  It's really quite gorgeous inside.  I couldn't pass up a tasty looking beet salad so I ordered one up.  It's a beautiful presentation with two unassuming fried goat cheese balls.  But holy crap were those some amazing balls!!  The beets were good, don't get me wrong... and I liked shallot vinaigrette, but those cheese balls... star of the show!  

I'd come back just for a plate full of those, even though I know it wouldn't be the healthiest option!  I definitely want to come back for dinner and get some of the other delicious sounding items and perhaps a cocktail.  It would be a nice date night spot.  Maybe even a romantical evening stay downtown at the hotel as well!  Fried cheese balls included in that package please!

After laboring over the mouth watering menu for 20 minutes trying to narrow down our choices, my normally decisive wife and I gave up, and ordered all appetizers so we could try more things.  We went with the Braised Short Rib Pierogies, Roasted Beet and Fried Goat Cheese Salad with Seared Salmon, Home Made Meatballs stuffed with Provolone and Mozzarella, and Seasonal Wild Mushroom Risotto.  It was all delectable, freshly, and attractively prepared, and every bit as delicious as it sounds.  

Besides getting to try more things, the appetizers were a good deal.  The small plate apps and salads are mostly around $10, while the main courses are mostly $30-$35.  Everything was excellent and felt like we got a very fair value.  

I should caution any would be dieters that most of the dishes tended to be on the heavier side.  Granted we brought it on ourselves with the cheese stuffed meatballs and short rib pierogies, but in truth most of the menu wasn't stingy with batter, bacon, cheese, sausage, butter, cream, and Bearnaise sauce.  If you're trying to avoid a post meal coma, you may have a hard time finding anything sin free.  That said, if you are up for an indulgence (Because let's face it, you've earned it) you'll have a hard time treating yourself better than Braddocks!

I stay at this hotel a lot when I travel to Pittsburgh for work. The restaurant has a great atmosphere. The food is excellent and the staff is very accommodating and very friendly. The manager walked around to the guest and asked how everything was. He was even helping the servers bring the food out. My steak was cooked PERFECT!! I ordered the filet mignon medium well and the chef cooked it perfect! It was very delicious. The dessert was amazing, croissant bread pudding. It's really a great place to eat and have a fun night out. I look forward to coming back.

J and I came here a 3 Friday's ago for a late dinner, around 10pm. The restaurant was closed, however the bar was still open and served the full menu. Steeler game was on, which is always nice. It was a pretty small space, approximately 7 tables and a moderate sized bar. It was also pretty loud, but that's to be expected. The menu was pretty cool as it showcases Pittsburgh's contribution to the Whiskey Rebellion and gave facts on the different types of whiskeys. I had a glass of white wine and j and I shared the cheese platter. For dinner, J had steak with asparagus and mashed potatoes and I had the jumbo lump crab cakes. Everything was pretty tasty. Our waiter was so welcoming and friendly, which made the overall experience great. It would have been nice to experience being in the restaurant, which closes at 10pm, but this was a nice alternative.

My friend and I started off in the bar. Our drinks were amazing. The bartender was great. He really paid attention to detail.
We had a great waitress named Autumn at the restaurant. I ate the crab cakes and asparagus. It was amazing. My friend had the steak and she said she was able to cut her filet with her butter knife it was so tender. The salads were good as well.
The only reason I give this four stars is because the restroom is out in the hotel, which is where their restaurant is located, and upstairs. Maybe this is a matter of them not having any space for a restroom in the restaurant, but it was annoying. Other than that, everything was perfect.

Nice ambiance.  Very good service.  Excellent menu variety.  Wonderful drink selection.

On another Yelper's recommendation I had the beet salad with fried goat cheese...magnificent!  I will go back JUST for that!  My 10 year old niece had a filet and veggies and cleaned her plate. The filet was delicious.  My mom had salmon and veggies...and it must have been wonderful because no one got a bite!  I also had the steak tartare...served with pork rinds!  LOVE!

A great place for a meal before the theatre...and what's not to love about the Renaissance!

I have eaten here on 3 occasions. Once was for brunch ,which was rather good. Once again for dinner, I had the hen special, a little salty but not bad. Again at a venue called Picklesburgh. They sold a sandwich called "Kielbasa Ban Mi" which was suppose to be a rendition of  Vietnamese sandwich. It was nothing of the sort. It was just cooked Kielbasa on a bun, and you pick your "pickling veggie" of choice. Very bland. The restaurant is a little over priced, however that's hotel restaurants for you.  The hotel lobby and atmosphere is very nice. The food, just quasi.
